Let's review this conversation and produce a first draft of the letter that i can send to dara and munir updated after all our work together, write a summary of the new insights, new themes, new questions, and write the first letter in full, here is our prior content: [[[Current letter to Munir and Dara, my cofounders at Bloom.pm a social impact accelerator and social enterprise support ecosystem: [[[
I’m writing to show you why I believe our systems emerge from our foundational beliefs and mindsets—about what the world is and what humans are. Like a dog that won't cross an electric fence, we are limited by our deepest assumptions, many of which are historically ingrained. The problem is that we have lost a way of relating to the world that honors quality and meaning over mere materiality, and I want to show you why reconnecting with that sense of depth helps us truly come alive. By coming alive and reconnecting with this lost way of seeing, we can build new kinds of systems that honor people as ends in themselves, not just means for achieving “impact,” “funding,” or “goals.”
Below, I’m going to walk you through:
Why emergent approaches matter more than rigid systems
Why our present mindset of “winners take all” and mastery is flawed
How honoring relationships, depth, and meaning (vs. breadth and metrics) can heal burnout
Why I think we can form a better foundation for Bloom.pm by coming alive first, then building systems
I’ll share the personal reflections, doubts, and inspirations that led me here. Then, I’ll remind you, in the end, what I told you.

Tell Them
Core Hypothesis: Systems Emerge From Our Foundational Beliefs
The suspicions I've been having about "winners take all" and that we can't take down the master's house with the master's tools are becoming clearer and clearer to me. I want to ensure that our work honors the non-instrumental nature of treating people as ends, not means to SDGs or impact, or stories to tell our donors. It's by doing the right things for the right reasons that we can be successful as human beings first, facing ourselves in the mirror. Honor and dignity are worth more than continued funding from donors who don't trust us to treat us well.
I am convinced that we need emergent approaches—good people and trust that they will do beautiful things—not good systems we attempt to shape people through. We are kind of limited by our foundational beliefs and understandings. Historically, these beliefs have led us to live in a way that is instrumental and transactional. We lost a different way we once had of seeing the world—one related to quality, to a sense of meaning, not just materiality.

Why Emergent Approaches Over Rigid Systems?
Even the idea that we can create systems of digital tools that scale and create an impact that is "out of our hands" is somehow missing something important. Our care and our connection are essential. We need to ensure that we are crafting something meaningful and beautiful—a system that honors the maker and the person using it, preserving their insight. There's something about relationship that we've been alienated from. We text instead of calling, we want to "blast" an email to thousands, and have systems with drop-offs at every stage instead of leaning into the connection and knowledge that grows from our spheres and through them to their spheres.
Through our connection with mentors, we can transmit these new ways of seeing and lived values—not as a list, but as a lived experience. This is how we can trust that they get it. We will know because we will see and feel it in our interactions with them. The idea that we can give a feedback form or an assessment and get answers from our mentors is only half right. They will only be able to share what they see with the eye of rationality. We need to see them with the eye of quality—the eye of Goodness, Truth, and Beauty—the eye that knows these things.

Critique of the “Winners Take All” Mindset
Developing skills and knowledge at the edge of our growth in the face of challenges means we need to be sincere about what we know and what we don't know, what we can do and what we can't. I believe that rushing into things because there is funding is a horrible reason to do something. What if we can get funding so people can know themselves, the world, and access what their hearts are calling them towards?
What if funding allowed us to go deeper, work with fewer, and support them as they worked it out, rather than pushing funding, expenditures, and movement that may be adding friction and doing a bunch of wrong things that'll need to be undone? With so much friction, we can certainly burn people out, as we've seen on our own teams. What are we really doing?

Relationships, Depth, and Healing Burnout
Then, we can have scalable systems where those people can impact others, rather than thinking about scale in breadth—showing how many people have jobs or planted trees. We need to get more comfortable with depth: how many people are having meaningful moments, finding their gifts, and sharing them in gratitude, making a more sincere, honest, and beautiful change versus one which has "good impact." Impact—the sound of a heavy book hitting the floor or an asteroid on the earth—reminds me of "fail fast and break things" and disruptive technologies. We don't need to be disruptive in these days; things are disruptive enough. We need to be a source of healing.
Why do we talk about wellbeing and stress? What if we aligned ourselves more humbly, took on projects that gave us deep connection, and built real community by helping everyone slow down enough to have community? We can move fast later when fast is what wants to happen. I know this sounds idealistic, and I know you worry about the business failing, and that's okay. I sort of think that business might need to go.

Foundational Beliefs and Historical Context
I don't know if you believe, as I do, that good things live and true things find their homes. If we don't focus on what we "can do to keep going" and truly focus on the problem that moves us and what brings us to life sincerely, if we are "eating our own dogfood," I think we'll find something. It might be small—who knows, maybe a team of two or three for a while—although I don't think that's so bad.
What if we found ways to help Bloom be a business we "want to do" rather than "have to do"? Perhaps we need to find other jobs to give us time to build the real thing we want to share with the world. Maybe we need time to reflect and can work like Einstein did at some desk job somewhere so we can think. Maybe our children happening, our contracts dwindling, isn't the time to rush. Maybe these are signs (if you believe in those things—perhaps you'd prefer signals) that we should slow down and think deeper. It's what I've been doing.

Personal Reflections: Coming Alive
I've been thinking about our time in Turkey and the idea of coming alive that was starting to come into resolution for me there. The ideas that there was something weird about helping people have goals for social change and getting them to take on the "habits and best practices to help them be most effective"—it's possible that I'm wrong, yet I think it's clearer than ever to me that this is not something I'm willing to subjugate. Initially, I thought I could draw on the "depth" of things, and the systems would help scale out to the "breadths" of things—that wellbeing and welldoing were possible to bring together in a harmonious balance.
Externally, that may be what people see when they witness someone like my friend Dug Song build businesses while being a family man, not leaving Detroit for Silicon Valley, and still skateboarding while building a business that sells for 2.x billion dollars. I think that this is not an accident and that it was not a set of systems that he took on or books he read. The idea of "habits of success" is so instrumental to me. If you think about it, you will use your will to compel your mind and body into specific patterns of behavior to achieve a goal. Your mind and body have become instruments for this goal. Is the goal worth it? Why do you think there's burnout, alienation, and why do you think even in the social sector there are bad actors who believe that the ends justify the means?

Relationality, Love, and Meaning as Ends
It's taken me a long time to accept the lessons I was given when I was younger, inspired by Father Greg Boyle. When they asked his intentions for doing his social enterprise, he didn't give some SDG that needed to be addressed or some "God told me to do it" nonsense. He said because they were his friends. Relationality, closeness, love, connection, and care—these are all ends, reasons to do things that no one should have to justify and might be impossible to justify because they are not perceived by the eye of rationality. They are perceived by the eye that knows what goodness is, what truth is, and what beauty is. That eye is the one that I would like to cultivate.
The Nietzsche quote, "He who has a strong enough why can overcome any how," guides me here. People who love have climbed mountains—"there ain't no mountain high enough," "there ain't no ocean vast enough"—to keep them away from the beauty they want to do. This is a real reason, a source of persistence, vitality, and passion to knock on a thousand doors until one opens. This is why they'll leave our heart-based aliveness-focused program and join Y Combinator to get what they need financially or figure something totally new and unexpected out.
I'm finally able to see why I care so much about community, the upside-down pyramid, starting with why, character strengths, and coming alive. It's not about some materialist interpretation of mindfulness-based stress reduction for people to better manage their emotions to do the nonsense they have committed to doing. It's about coming to view emotions as messengers, to look through them into the place they touch your heart. Why do we feel sad when we see animals going extinct? What about that is meaningful for us that's being lost? Think about it, feel into it, see what echoes within you. Those emotions are treasures, and we are constantly being played by a masterful orchestra.

Emotions as Messengers of Meaning
Each tense emotion tells us something about a blocked source of meaning. Each positive emotion is a gift to enjoy, persist, and sink into what we're doing without being attached. Contentedness is not an emotion; it's a state. I believe these states are profoundly important to the idea of why we should be doing things and can be found when we tap into our sources of meaning, come alive, and heed their calls with small, bold actions. Similar to the zone described by the flow state, where our skills are at the edge of our capacity and the challenge we're at, we can gradually find the next emerging way of being by responding to the constant flow of calls.

Where the Current System Falls Short
This means trust, implies process, and moves people, businesses, projects, and more from a system of semi-static parts to an alive, organic whole that cannot be segmented, assessed with forms, analyzed, projected into the future, and planned. It's the reality that it's hubris to think otherwise. It's part of the insanity about why the iNGOs are more than happy to give us jobs, yet are silent when it comes to keeping us alive (Palestinians and Lebanese). We saw how let down the people who can see this hypocrisy felt. It's so true though—the goals, the SDGs, the plans—these things are dead on arrival. The reality of being responsive, being real, being caring, being human and humane is lost to the organizations focused on the attainment of something.
I know this all probably sounds crazy. In fact, I'm confident that since you've known me long enough, you might accept it a bit more. Yet for me, it took a while to finally deconstruct a few things, starting with Aristotle and the idea of classification. Aristotle’s metaphysics focus on cause-and-effect relationships (final cause, material cause) percolate like water through the grounds of Western culture and get amplified by the mechanistic thinking of the Scientific Revolution (Descartes, Newton). It's just a brain watching a world of parts interact—sort of system thinking, Hobbes. Oh crap, Christians are killing each other; we're totally horrible, and we need a rational government to put things in order. Systems should be what we follow, not people. Enlightenment off with his headism, individualist pieces that can reason best for themselves, laden with democratic American ideas like "let's pick happiness as a teleological conclusion," etc.

Historical Roots and a Lost Way of Seeing
We live in a soulless world of rational objects, bodies needing food, cause-effect transactions in a swirl of beautiful elegance making a souffle out of anthropology, biology, chemistry, physics, and the mathematics that Galileo said is the perfect way to describe the world. It can all be displayed as a nice little infographic—the world is made of markets transacting materiality. The hard problem of consciousness is irrelevant when we have people dying of malaria, and we go fix that because death is bad. What about not living at all, not coming alive, becoming a machine, giving up your ability to sense meaning and connect to true purpose for some fear-based worry your philosophical forefathers (that most have no idea about or understand the impact of the history of ideas) had?
We're here because of someone else's war, freaking people out. Our systems destroy the planet due to seeing humans as human resources for a machine that's efficiently transforming materiality into material to satisfy the needs and desires of humans. If there aren't enough desires to create enough demand to necessitate the improvement of the systems and optimization to achieve goals more efficiently, because hey, what rational person wouldn't want cheaper tomatoes? Who cares if we breed them to be transported across the ocean and have no idea what that does to the flavor, let alone nutritional profile?

It’s About Our Way of Seeing, Not Just Different Goals
We must use these fear-based epistemologies and ontologies that see the world full of nasty, brutish people who will die shortly unless we use our reason to align with the reason of the natural world, to break it up into little pieces and use it to our favor. And BTW, the people who think like this are more likely to be skiing in the Alps and owning businesses than running them. Also, their kids don't go to public schools and get graded like screws and meat of varying quality. By the way, I'm more of a B/B+ sort of person than a Grade A, so here, doing this thinking is a bit out of my weight class. Yet I digress, and I try anyway to help you see, feel, and understand this foundational thing.
It's NOT about the wrong goals, profit or SDGs. It's not even about the systems leveraging personal and professional growth to help transform the economic system into one that's better for people and the planet. No, it's about the way of seeing and understanding what a person is, what the world is, and the systems that emerge from that understanding.

Reconnecting With Meaning for New Systems to Emerge
Our neoliberal order is sort of a beautiful system that is hard to argue with. Market efficiency sort of works, as does reductionist science as we break atoms further down into their core. We can understand the material and superficial world and can move things, energy, resources, and food—all commodities—which the markets manage, valuing perfectly well. The problem is there is no reason for this elegant dance of a billion buy-sell decisions mostly run by machines. There is only short-sighted efficiency of materiality.
I've tried not to say God in this run-on paragraph. Yet it's a bit hard not to, so how about you look at your favorite person, a loved one, and convince yourself they are a "user" of Instagram, a customer of Zara, or a citizen of a country—little pinballs bouncing around in the systems of goals and accomplishments of others. What about your feeling of love? That's some oxytocin and some serotonin floating around a bloodstream in a body that wants to keep its bodily integrity intact so that it can propagate itself and not die. You cannot learn Darwin's theory and believe it without hurting your soul a little bit. There are people who die for beauty—don't you know? There are things that matter more than life itself. You know this; you may have even felt this if you're lucky. Yet we have no way in our modern mindset to understand it, where we can place it, what power this is that is ultimately lost.
These things have been bugging me for a long time. I started in education, realizing the issue with the control systems being forced on children—full of aliveness and dreams, shaping them into consumers and workers. I saw the post-WWII economic system require us to win the war of ideas and ensure that capitalism produces power and material success, and we did it at our own expense. Sure, this is all fine, said typing on a MacBook Pro made by a capitalist company with $216 billion in cash reserves, benefiting from the international trade that brings me coffee from Ethiopia to my door and markets that pressure countries to fight on my behalf so everything is affordable and safe.
Yet I think it doesn't have to be revolutionary. I think the simple act of finding that part of us that can see and feel what beauty and goodness are and asking it what it needs to shine and doing that—a little each day. Weirdly enough, for me, it's writing you this long letter. I was going to use AI to help clean it up and summarize and make it all polished, yet somehow I think that goes against my point here. We need to see each other, even our messy selves. This is from my heart to yours. I'm writing this with you, Dara, and you, Munir, in mind.
It's been a long struggle for me, starting before 2022 in Turkey—where I've felt off, yet I acquiesced, allowing my doubt in my own feelings to fester. I thought maybe he's right. Maybe we can keep doing/building this way. Maybe I'm wrong. Maybe there's a productive tension. I mentioned these ideas of coming alive in the retreat, although I think I didn't realize at the time that that's the foundational thing I want to do—the upside-down pyramid, self-efficacy, character strengths, notes journal, breakout rooms, one-on-ones, the 1% better journey were about that. Goals can come not from a dream of a desired future state, but they can emerge from becoming the kind of person who achieves that goal. Don't plan to run a marathon; become a runner. We've talked about these.
Yet more foundationally, this clarity shows me the kinds of things to focus on: we should measure at the end of the day and attend to our sources of meaning at the start. The story of self and the story of the world can and must be discovered and grown so we can allow our qualitative witnessing to see, echo, resonate with, and inspire knowledge and action. Togetherness matters, being a mirror matters, finding emotions is precious, discerning between emotions and states matters, goals can be had, yet ways of being we admire are what we must engender and practice. We can go slow, be gentle with ourselves, and be successful once we start on the path to self-knowledge and alignment with values, perception, and enaction.
I think sometimes you must think that I'm crazy, and perhaps I am. Although I'm working on developing my ideas, gathering stories (microfinance was beautiful, right? Amu Yunus got a Nobel Prize, cool? Well, we're seeing the fruits of not foundationally changing the perception of what finance is, what money is, what it serves. What a human is with a spate of suicides as a result of not being able to pay the petty sum back and being hounded by people who are achieving "targets"—targets, pretty grim).
I'm working on developing this into a clearer vision of what I think my work in "social impact" can be, what I think the problems are of burnout and lack of wellbeing. And no, it's not only because we don't have money for paid holidays; there's something burning about using yourself for something that is not yourself. We can cultivate gardens of conditions—we must treat people as ends and get close. Relationships matter, commitment matters, connection matters. Scale can happen in a beautiful and authentic way, probably not in the way we plan, where we draw hockey stick charts and hope and hope again.
I sometimes think perhaps I've been saved from success because I'm not sure I would have had the time, perspective, and frustration, quite frankly, to see as I do. Am I just "sourgraping" this whole thing? I don't think so. I think indigenous economics—talking about cyclical time (not linear) thinking, seven generations (not retiring when I'm 40), relationships with a world of meaning (not humans and nature as resources to extract)—are similar. Yet indigenous economics stays small and sort of implies we must take their principles and ways of doing things rather than discovering them ourselves in our own indigeneity—our Lebanese indigenous economics—emerging from systems built by people who have reintegrated both eyes, seeing with reason and logic and the eyes of meaning and quality. Being confident enough to know we need to be wary of too much planning in an era of collapse. We need to live in a way that when the bombs drop or the seas start rising, we are confident we did what we were made to do and were successful at every step of the way, no matter if we arrived wherever we thought we might or not.

Remind Them of What We Told Them
So there you have it. I’ve told you about:
How our systems emerge from deep-seated beliefs and mindsets
Why emergent approaches and depth of relationship matter more than quick, scalable fixes
How transactional and instrumental thinking leads to burnout, while real connection can heal and help us come alive
Why the historical context of our beliefs has stripped us of a sense of meaning and how reconnecting with that meaning might guide us forward
I hope this short essay made some sense. I wanted to share this to see if you have feedback, what gaps were in my logic. I think this is what I want to do next for work: to operationalize this process of first recognizing the perceptual faculty that we're being gaslit not to identify (artists usually are pretty clear about this, good ones at least). That faculty can see things and know things that are both reliable and true—just as reason can see and we can deduce truth, we can do that with quality as well.
By finding that and living it more in our lives, we come alive, and by coming alive we bring energy and goodness, building capacity, skills, relationships, knowledge, stories of self, stories of world—essentially forging a new foundation for new systems to emerge. We all need to awaken the artist within us to help us weave a more beautiful story that is just as true, and perhaps more true, to undo the fragility of systems and unearth the beauty and humility of emergence.
I don't think I intend to "get by" anymore with my work. I have to share what I know, or I shrivel up and help no one. I remember being asked in 2016 to make an entrepreneurship program, and I thought it was silly to have everyone do the same assignments. I thought it would be cool to direct people to the things they needed with technology. Today, I'm going back again and having another one of those moments where I can't do the same thing anymore. I need to do something different, something beautiful, and I'd love to do it with you—if you're in with me :)

Warm regards,
Bilal Ghalib
]]]
A personal essay showing my experience with beauty, struggle accepting inner quality recognition and my path towards integration: 
[[[Okay, so we're going to be writing an essay with our voice because one of my skills and competencies and something that I pride myself in is my ability to follow a thread clearly and coherently and articulated, and this content must be mine and come from my heart and not be external and also it must be connected to all realities. It's my intention that this becomes a snapshot of my thinking about the truths that I've discovered in my life and the realities they imply towards a good life and how that impacts the sense of speed, rush, fear, otherness, alienation, and impending disaster with the climate, the wars the mistrust of our neighbors and the lack of time and space and knowledge of what to do with ourselves. I'm indebted to my mom who shared with me in October of 2011 their aid prayer from Mecca, and in that prayer there was a talk and in that talk the speaker, shared the idea that God is beautiful, and he loves that which is beautiful and in that time, I was very hurt and unable to accept all of the tradition that I had been raised with because it was getting in the way of me trusting my heart, and that tension the reality that this person I respected and admired was some one that my heart honestly could lean towards and brought me aliveness was fighting with the textual reality of the lack of an articulated Islam or Christianity that I could check some box in an accounting system with the god and with my family to say that this woman is a Muslim and therefore I am allowed to have these feelings. rather than the fear, hope, trepidation, openness, wonder anticipation heart opening heart racing, mind spinning possibility, of accepting love.  I remember laying down on the ground outside and she asked me, do you love me? and rather than taking a moment to take a deep breath to look inside of my heart, and to say the truth of what I found, I deflected. I asked for literalism.  I asked how do you define love? There are places within us that know love that can distinguish love from lust and in my confusion and desire to be confused to avoid the pain and the stress and the fear of confronting my family and confronting the check box guard and religion that I had invented that wasn't the true way of interpreting are the only way I deflected and created confusion in my life and compounded that confusion for years and years I allowed myself in that confusion to create a shadow and to have the part of me that was alive to live in that shadow. I nook out of the house in the dark to be able to be with the parts of me that were actually alive and I lived like a zombie, having not slept and like a zombie because in the day I was living waiting for the night distant from my heart, distant from the thing that knows the truths of the world and the truths within myself. and in October 2011 I was given one of the keys of a trifecta that allowed me to open my heart and to connect reintegrate with my emotions, with my feelings, with my perception of beauty, with my sense of meaning and sense of self, and ultimately, at long last, the realizations that beauty is the splendor of truth. and beauty is that which draws you into love, and that the perception and recognition of beauty is a part of a faculty that is inextricable from that perception and that reality.  This faculty within us that sees beauty is the place where we can answer the questions of what is true and the confusions that we might have about what is actually good How should we live? What is real? My background as someone who loves science and technology and philosophy and rationalizations.  I think connects to this desire for control and this lack of engaging with the fear and the reality of the bird that when it wakes up and opens its eyes and sees its hungry children, and leaves its nest in fear and hope, seeking the worms, the seeds, the sustenance and the awe in the wonder and the gratitude and the aliveness at finding it. This way of seeing the world and living in the world requires both eyes, we do have a rational faculty We can think ahead to plant seeds now to organize our land, to let land rest after understanding soil depletion so that we can have a better harvest next year and I've realized that this love of planning and stability along with my rejection of the tradition that was brought to me that was teaching me how to open the eye of the heart. limited me from being able to explore in an open way, and the only way that's real on the tight rope of life to keep my eyes focused on beauty and to walk without looking down knowing and not knowing that the next step is going to land and that will be okay and that will make it. because the rope is invisible to the tight rope walker. It's just sensed, just like the worm is invisible to the bird. and in the muslin tradition were given many promises of what happens to those who trust and have god consciousness that these are those that are successful.  And these beliefs I think must be taken gradually, step by step. You take one step, that proves the rope is there, you leave one morning, you find the worms, but winter comes, things change, the wind blows, and the rope moves ever so slightly. and so I believe that it's not that we must avoid planning planting the seeds and using our mind, but that we need as a society to traverse this canyon. We are in a place where our stasis is destructive, our not changing is damaging, and I believe the roots of why staying the same is damaging is connected to the roots that have alienated us from this perception of beauty and truth and goodness, and even trusting that this means something that it's not an emotion only that it may have states ways that are uplifting inspire us.  You watch a movie about Nelson Mandela and you leave uplifted the sense of possibility and hope and maybe you think to yourself, how can I be a little more like that? And so the first thing that happened to me after my partner broke up with me because I could not face the fear. of the reality that was being that was beckoning the reality of I love this person and I don't know what to do. I'm young I don't know my faith.  I don't know myself. I don't know what love actually means. that love is the splendor of truth and that beauty and truth and love come together and that if I wanted to know God and how to live I have to read all three books the book of revelation, the book of inner insight and looking within our feelings, our thoughts, even our negative ruminations, and the book of the outer world the beauty of a river flowing down a mountain and a waterfall, and fish below in a clear pond eating the bugs on the river and then if you follow that river as it passes through human civilization on the other side, you look again into the water, and you find ugliness, a weird slimy color, a film on the top of the water potentially dead fish, a bad smell it repulses you. and why is that the case? How is this also true and how is that assign?  These signs of repulsion could have prevented us from continuing down this path the they would say the smell of London in the 1800s the squalor the tight neighborhoods with sewage flowing down the middle and Jack the Ripper and the pollution bellowing into the air and kids coming home in the morning after working at night shift in a factory and injuries and I'm sure people knew this wasn't beautiful. yet it helped increase the sense of control because there was a a power to it that could be grown resources accumulating into the hands of the owners allowing more allocating according to their desires and whims, unchecked and unpurified and unhe held up against the example of beauty and this alienation from the things that make life meaningful, require us to fill it with a hope that the future will be better. I don't feel so good right now, but I believe in this progress that we're making, this idea of progress links in deeply with this idea of how the reward system within us works. our sense of accomplishments and reward and the molecule dopamine that symbolizes it is not from achievement. It's not from making a goal and accomplishing it.  The reward comes from the expectation of a good, and so as long as we were able to tell ourselves in each other, this world might not be good to day, but to morrow it will be better when technology improves when we're able to extract more from less when we have to work less, this claim that, you know, we increase productivity and somehow work less and enjoy more is not what has happened at all. We've increased productivity and working hours, and at the same time we're reducing wages. This confusion about what is good, what do we want from life, this sense of mastery has been possible for only 200300 years and it was made possible from the primary disconnect from people with some their core faculty that is able to see and then the practice of implementing the seeing of beauty into a cycle of life that shows that you can take another step on that tight rope towards a more beautiful future and instead we went into a command and control into a cycle of allowing the things that think a we are able to control our situation and preserve our station and expand our domination and to manage people and the planet and the colonies and to do all of this in a way where we start having the science of productivity and the science of the polity and political science and we have this illusion of being able to get what we want without ever opening the eyes within us that can know what we actually want, and with only one eye, we can only see what we think we want, our needs, our fears, our expectations, and we try to address those, but it's it's a bottomless pit because the only thing that can really fill those is the eye that is able to see our true desires for love, beauty, connection, and the things that are truly satisfying.  And so what happens as we fall into lust or we fall into gluttony, or we fall into laziness, and we build escalators, and then when our bodies start falling apart, we go to the gym. And so understanding that dohamine is this reward molecule, I think is really important to see why we always imagine heaven as to morrow and that promise that things will be better, I think, kept people in a cage of anticipation and patience. of gritting our teeth kind of patience, but then, as we see in to day's world, we see that our uncontrolled, desire for control has expanded our unbeautiful ways of being into manipulating more of the world into ugliness into factories that fall on the people working to make our clothes and into promoting consumption just to be able to maintain the systems into this problematic situation that we find ourselves in that I think really is exemplified by this disconnect between this faculty that knows what is actually good and beautiful rather than the faculty that sees and wants for oneself, it's the faculty that sees and in that seeing can be satisfied in the connection and relating and and then we can talk very plainly about the rise of suicide. uh being one of the leading causes of death for young people, the beginning of suicides in preteens, which is unthinkable and it is kind of vague sense of anxiety they say that in the last 30 years the levels of anxiety have skyrocketed around the world, and we're coming to a place where I think we have to open that other eye. And I think so many people know this and part of the taste of it was during the pandemic when people uh were unable to go to the work that they were distracted by they started making sour dough, right?  connecting to the arts and to the crafts and to sharing, like you don't make a whole loaf of sourdough and eat it by yourself, and you don't even make the sourdough by yourself, you make it in collaboration with the yeast, and you wait and there's this recognition of a beauty in working with systems, working within and for systems, and they might think of it as a silly example, but as more people looked into their own lives and asked like, I'm at home and I'm with myself. # A New Direction for Bloom: Reclaiming Craft and Quality

## Part I: My Personal Journey

**Dear Dara and Munir,**

Over the past few years, I’ve felt an increasing tension between the *hearts* of the social entrepreneurs we serve and the *systems* we’ve used to support them. I remember a pivotal moment in Dubai:

- **Marie Claire’s Story:** She spoke about feminine hygiene issues—topics considered shameful in her community—and how she not only invented cheaper, more sustainable products but also created safe spaces for women to speak freely about their bodies. As she shared her journey—financing this project out of thin air, gathering agricultural waste to produce tampons, and building an entire community of supportive women—tears filled the room. It wasn’t her metrics or business model that moved us; it was her love and courage. In those moments, I saw the power of *real meaning* in action.

- **Contrast With Bloom’s Approach:** Flash back to our own internal meetings, where we’d draw **hockey-stick growth charts** on whiteboards for a platform almost no one was using. Fear of “wasting our savings” and chasing “funder demands” overshadowed the deeper, living reality. When I felt that *gnawing frustration*, I initially dismissed it as just my mood. But eventually, I realized it was my *quality perception* telling me something was off—something was missing from how we were designing Bloom’s programs.

I felt *stifled, small, and passive* in leadership meetings, not wanting to create friction or show “a divided front.” My doubts clashed with the story we were telling donors and participants about “big impact” and “scalable solutions.” The mismatch between my internal knowing and our external messaging created a sense of *inner conflict and anger*—but I didn’t yet have the language to articulate what was wrong.

---

## Part II: Realizing the Missing Piece—Quality Perception

Over time, through reading, reflection, and talking to other changemakers, I recognized that **my frustration was a valid sign** of deeper truths:

- **Quality Perception Is Real:** It’s not just an emotion; it’s a *perceptual faculty* that lets us sense when something is “alive” and meaningful versus when it’s forced or artificial. Father Greg Boyle’s work with gang members—grounded in authentic friendship rather than an “impact formula”—resonates with this idea. It’s a way of *seeing* what truly matters, beneath the metrics and the goals.

- **Map vs. Territory:** We were over-relying on the *map* (plans, metrics, funder demands) instead of continuously checking the *territory* (real human needs, genuine relationships, actual traction). When we rely solely on the map, we can wander off-course, building solutions with no soul or actual adoption.

- **Craft Over Factory:** In so many sectors—**Buurtzorg** in healthcare, **Sounds True** in publishing, **Mondragón** in cooperatives—authentic, craft-like approaches thrive. People *slow down*, trust *master-apprentice relationships*, and *directly perceive* what’s needed, rather than forcing top-down goals or arbitrary timelines.

## Part III: Core Shifts Needed at Bloom

Here are the shifts I believe will bring Bloom *closer to real impact*—and allow us to serve participants like Marie Claire more authentically.

### 1. From Individual Programs to **Relational Development**

- **Current Problem**: We design linear curricula, isolated exercises, or abstract frameworks that treat participants as if they each have the same needs.
- **Craft Approach**: 
  - **Master-Apprentice**: Identify masters (people who truly embody quality) and connect them with those seeking mentorship.  
  - **Community Learning**: Foster circles or cohorts where relationships naturally form.  
  - **Direct Transmission**: Let the *wisdom* of experience flow, rather than packaging everything as slide decks or checklists.

### 2. From Rigid Programs to **Practice Spaces**

- **Current Problem**: Fixed curricula, defined outcomes, and metric-driven timelines reduce flexibility and can strangle the spark of real innovation.
- **Craft Approach**: 
  - **Creating Conditions**: We create space for participants to experiment and build their own solutions at a natural pace.  
  - **Enabling Emergence**: Instead of top-down “deliverables,” we let the process evolve from ongoing feedback.  
  - **Quality Recognition**: Support participants in learning to *recognize* what’s working or resonating deeply (territory) rather than imposing from a map.  
  - **Natural Timing**: Some breakthroughs are rapid, others need more gestation.

### 3. From Content to **Transmission of Wisdom**

- **Current Problem**: We often emphasize “information transfer”—best practices, skill checklists, or standard metrics.
- **Craft Approach**: 
  - **Wisdom Sharing**: Bring in people like Father Greg Boyle or others who exemplify a “living example” approach.  
  - **Direct Experience**: Encourage participants to do real projects in real contexts, with immediate feedback, so they *feel* what quality looks like.  
  - **Living Examples**: Feature stories from Mondragón, Sounds True, Buurtzorg, not as “case studies” but as living demonstrations of different ways of working.

In my personal life, I experienced a parallel tension around love. That same displacement—**asking the mind to handle something the heart perceives directly**—showed up in my work at Bloom. I’d been ignoring the deeper “territory” of people’s lived experiences, clinging instead to the “map” of metrics and donor-friendly systems.

### **Recognition vs. Reason**

Eventually, I realized I possessed a legitimate **perceptual faculty**—a way to see quality directly, not as a hunch or fleeting emotion, but as something akin to “vision.” Father Greg’s authenticity, Tami Simon’s “feels right,” and my own frustration at meaningless metrics were signs that we all have an innate capacity to sense *when something is alive and good*.

At the time, I didn’t have the language to articulate this. I thought maybe I was just moody or rebellious, but as I listened to other people’s stories and kept encountering this tension, I realized it was pointing to a *fundamental problem* in how we do social impact: **we treat people and programs as instruments to achieve outcomes**, rather than cultivating the deeper sources of meaning that actually generate those outcomes in the first place.

## **II. The Root Problem: One-Eyed Vision**

### **Factory Thinking and the Trap of Metrics**

Like many in social enterprise, we believed that scaling impact meant “build a bigger system.” We created platforms, enforced sign-ups, tried to gather data to refine the system further. But it felt forced. We’d run *evaluation forms*, push participants to fill them out so we could “improve,” and ask them to log onto our custom tools daily. Whenever we asked, “Why aren’t they using it?” the hidden answer was that no one truly *wanted* it. The system served *our* goals, not theirs.

We had begun seeing the world through a single lens—**the map** of goals, metrics, projections. We wanted **hockey-stick growth**: sign-ups, daily active users, more and more. But inside, I felt a quiet voice protesting: “*Is this real? Are we sure we’re not just forcing a narrative for funders?*” Each time I ignored that voice, the tension grew.

### **Two Eyes: The Map and the Territory**

I now see this as a **one-eyed approach**: we rely on the “metrics eye” while neglecting the “quality eye.” In traveling, a good map is invaluable—**but only** if we also look at the land. No matter how detailed, a map can’t replace direct perception. We were letting the map overshadow the actual territory of entrepreneurs’ needs and experiences.

**The territory** includes intangible aspects: trust, self-discovery, relationships, meaning, presence. These are notoriously hard to measure, but ignoring them doesn’t make them less real. In fact, they’re the **most real** elements fueling human motivation, creativity, and resilience. The “metrics eye” is fine if used second, to confirm or reflect on what the “territory eye” sees first. Instead, we started with metrics, forcing people into checkboxes.

### **Burnout from Instrumentality**

Our approach to well-being was similarly instrumental: “Don’t burn out, so you can keep producing results.” This fosters a subtle cynicism. True well-being arises when we’re living in alignment, so that the work *itself* nourishes us. If we approach “wellness” solely as a technique to sustain productivity, we remain fundamentally misaligned, fueling the same tension that leads to eventual breakdown.

The deeper heartbreak was seeing how this overshadowed the **actual beauty** in people’s ventures. In Dubai, we met entrepreneurs with jaw-dropping personal stories—like **Marie Claire** turning agricultural waste into affordable feminine hygiene products, fighting stigma, and transforming entire school communities. Our “data push” to get her on a platform was dwarfed by the *real transformation* happening in her life. She was forging new spaces for women to feel safe, forging bonds of solidarity. **That** is the territory we should have honored, not overshadowed with “usage stats.”

## **III. Gardens, Craft, and the Deeper Way of Seeing**

### **Gardening as Metaphor**

A more aligned approach appears when we compare our social impact attempts to **gardening**. Yes, the gardener has a goal: grow tomatoes. But no gardener can “force” a plant to grow. Instead, the gardener creates the right conditions—good soil, water, nutrients, protection from pests—and then *observes*. She’s in an ongoing relationship with the plants. This is a slow, continuous dance of hope, trust, and gentle care, balanced with planning for inevitable challenges.

This stands in contrast to factory farming—pumping in chemicals, demanding uniform results, measuring outputs in a mechanistic way. The gardener is still measuring (moisture levels, spacing, yield), but these metrics serve her direct observation. She trusts natural processes and her own experience, learning from each season.

### **Craft: A Relationship of Maker, Material, and Meaning**

Craft is another illuminating metaphor. A skilled potter doesn’t just follow a blueprint; she senses the clay’s texture, moisture, the wheel’s speed, her own subtle hand pressure. **Measurement** is there (knowing dimensions, time in the kiln) but integrated into a deeper synergy of observation and feel.

- **Relational**: The craftsperson forms a bond with the material, shaping it in conversation rather than imposing shape from on high.  
- **Progressive Mastery**: She respects tradition—one doesn’t innovate on day one. Picasso learned classical drawing before breaking forms.  
- **Embedded Wisdom**: Traditional craft is sustainable by default—using local materials, mindful of waste, building community knowledge.

This is how social enterprises could operate: each venture as a craft, each participant shaping their unique path with guidance from experienced mentors, not hammered by impersonal systems. The difference is a matter of depth, presence, and trusting the *eye* that perceives quality.

### **When “Smooth Is Fast”**

Rushing leads to mistakes. Picture the cook who tries to hurry dinner, drops a jar of beans, and ends up taking longer overall. In craft, “slow is smooth, smooth is fast.” By respecting a certain natural timing, we ironically become more efficient, because we aren’t constantly reversing errors born of haste.

In **Buurtzorg**, for instance, trusting frontline nurses to manage patient care “slower” at the start meant less bureaucracy, higher patient satisfaction, and ultimately cost savings. Or **Sounds True**, which invests time in deep editorial curation, ironically leading to enduring content that outperforms quick market-chasing strategies. The consistent theme is that emergent, presence-based approaches yield outcomes that mechanistic approaches often fail to attain.

## **IV. Meeting Real Examples: Where Craft and Emergence Thrive**

### **1. Buurtzorg (Healthcare)**  
Buurtzorg in the Netherlands dismantled much of the top-down structure of traditional home-care organizations. They let nurses form self-managing teams, trusting them to decide patient care. Instead of layering managers and forms upon them, Buurtzorg invests in essential support and fosters autonomy. The *metrics* that eventually emerged—improved patient outcomes, lower overhead—were byproducts of trusting skilled humans on the ground.

### **2. Mondragón (Cooperatives)**  
Spain’s Mondragón Cooperative Corporation is a sprawling network of worker-owned companies, built on *dignity and trust.* During economic crises, they opted for shared wage reductions over layoffs, preserving community spirit. They maintained high innovation rates precisely because people felt personally invested and recognized as ends, not means to a corporate end.

### **3. Patagonia (Outdoor Apparel)**  
Patagonia’s famed “Don’t Buy This Jacket” campaign discouraged consumerism, focusing on environmental impact over revenue. Ironically, the authenticity propelled growth. *Quality recognition*—valuing the Earth over short-term sales—resonated deeply with customers. CEO Yvon Chouinard shows how moral authenticity can coexist with (and even enhance) financial success.

### **4. Sounds True (Publishing)**  
Tami Simon started Sounds True guided by an internal sense of what “felt right,” publishing spiritual and contemplative materials she deemed valuable. Over decades, this approach built trust with a niche audience that expanded far beyond niche. The metrics eventually confirmed the success, but that was never the driving force.

### **5. Morning Star (Tomato Processing)**  
Though a more industrial example, Morning Star eliminated traditional hierarchies, letting each employee negotiate responsibilities directly with colleagues. They still measure efficiency, but it’s embedded in a culture of personal autonomy and direct accountability. This is reminiscent of craft: balancing rational processes with trust in each individual’s capacity to sense what’s needed.

All these examples share one trait: they didn’t discard metrics or reason, but **prioritized trust, relationship, and direct perception** of what’s meaningful. They let systems *serve* the people involved, not the other way around.

## **V. Re-Envisioning Bloom: From Forced Funnels to Flourishing Gardens**

### **Recognizing Our True Craft**

What, then, is Bloom’s unique craft? After years of external programs, platform-building, and meandering, I see that our real gift is **facilitation, mentorship, and the creation of safe, reflective spaces**. Entrepreneurs often come to us feeling alone, uncertain, or cut off from their deeper motivations. We excel at:

- Holding space so they can articulate what truly matters.  
- Helping them see fear-based behaviors and shift toward grounded, value-aligned action.  
- Connecting them to mentors who embody trust and wisdom rather than imposing a one-size-fits-all approach.

If that is our craft, why did we bury it under forced software usage or inflated “impact stories” for donors? Fear. Fear that we weren’t legitimate unless we built a high-tech solution or chased big funder demands. But as technology moves forward (AI making our old platform obsolete), we see that **our ephemeral software** was never the real source of our impact.

### **Abandoning the Frenzied Instrumentality**

We’ve also recognized how a “frenzied, metric-chasing” mindset can ironically undermine the deep transformations we want. People sense when they’re being used for data. Entrepreneurs might fill out forms or log in daily, but their hearts remain distant. The halfhearted compliance never translates into real growth.

By **letting go** of that approach, we remove the friction that keeps us from deeper relationships. Instead of seeing people as means to demonstrate “scale,” we see them as ends in themselves—each with a personal journey that might not fit linear program timelines. As a result, participants become co-creators rather than subjects.

### **Practical Changes at Bloom**

1. **Piloting a “Come Alive” Cohort**  
   - We gather a small group, focusing on emotional clarity, presence, and personal alignment. Rather than drown them in content or software tasks, we guide them through *reflective dialogue*, shared stories, and targeted coaching.  
   - This approach is free or subsidized initially—an experiment in trust. Then, if participants find genuine value, we transition to a paid model that’s openly explained.

2. **Shifting Our Funding Model**  
   - We actively seek **funders who respect emergent, craft-like approaches**. We emphasize story-based impact, real transformations, and relational metrics (like depth of mentor-participant bonds).  
   - We move away from funders who force standard “reporting frameworks” that reduce participants to data points.

3. **Rethinking Technology**  
   - We don’t kill all tech; we simply ensure it solves *actual* problems. We start small, maybe using a shared spreadsheet or Slack channel. Only if a repeated need surfaces—like participants consistently requesting a scheduling tool—do we consider building (or integrating) a solution.  
   - This “just-in-time” approach aligns with craft thinking: build only what naturally emerges from real use-cases.

4. **Mentor/Team Onboarding**  
   - Each prospective mentor or staff member experiences a short “boot camp” around these principles. They learn to trust participants’ capacity, help them cultivate presence, and measure outcomes only in ways that reflect genuine growth.  
   - If a mentor insists on imposing a rigid checklist or has no interest in emotional presence, they might not fit Bloom’s new ethos.

### **The Future We Could Create**

If we do this well, **entrepreneurs** will experience Bloom not as another accelerator that “demands deliverables” but as a space that fosters *self-knowledge, confidence, and deeper connection to meaning*. They’ll discover mentors genuinely interested in their journeys. They’ll see *wellbeing* not as a side module but as an intrinsic part of doing work that resonates with who they are.

**Our team** will step into the role of “gardeners.” We still plan, but we plan in ways that **honor emergence**, trusting that the participants’ seeds hold potential we can’t fully script. We guide, reflect, and protect them from external pressures that stunt growth. We measure at the *end of the day*, not to push or coerce, but to confirm how things are unfolding.

**Our partners**—donors, collaborators—become co-creators. We invite them into the process, letting them see the honesty of our approach. We share real stories, tensions, successes, and failures. They, too, might connect with their own sources of meaning, shifting from a “transactional” to a “relational” engagement with Bloom.

## **VI. Conclusion: Trusting the Source of Meaning**

Looking back, I realize that my deep unrest around Al Jazeera, my heartbreak in seeing forced usage of platforms, my fascination with Father Greg Boyle, and the revelations in Dubai were all signposts pointing to a single truth: **we have a faculty that perceives quality directly**—and ignoring it leads to dead ends.

The question is whether we, as a social impact organization, can muster the courage to **trust that perception** in how we design, fund, and operate. Doing so implies a radical realignment:

- We treat participants as *ends* with unique calls and sources of meaning, not just as means to prove our impact.  
- We place rational metrics in the service of deeper emergent realities, never the other way around.  
- We let ourselves slow down, trusting that “smooth is fast,” that by caring for the “territory” first, we’ll find a more robust, life-giving path—and ironically, more enduring success.  
- We adopt the gardening and craft metaphors not as poetic flourishes but as operational guides, building robust relationships that reflect personal mastery, local wisdom, emotional intelligence, and timeless humility.

**Father Greg** taught me that “friends” are the reason to do social impact, not a metric or a logic model. **Buurtzorg** showed me that giving autonomy to frontline caregivers can reduce costs and bureaucracy more effectively than any top-down system. **Patagonia** taught me that moral authenticity can be a catalyst for growth, not an obstacle. **Sounds True** reminded me that “this feels right” can be a viable North Star for business decisions. **Mondragón** revealed how solidarity and dignity can thrive in a large-scale cooperative economy.

All of these encourage me to **look with both eyes**—the eye for data and the eye for direct perception of quality. If Bloom reorients itself around these guiding insights, we might discover that what we feared losing—scale, funding, recognition—actually follows naturally when we *align with real meaning*.

The path ahead isn’t easy. We’ll need to navigate donors’ expectations, internal habit loops, and the comfort of the old system. But every signpost—from personal love struggles, to uneasy media invites, to tears in Dubai—tells me it’s the only path truly worth taking. If we let go of partial vision, we can reclaim the fullness of what social impact is meant to be: a garden of emergent possibilities, a crafted work of art that grows in beauty because we trusted the deeper sources of meaning within ourselves and each other.
